I must confess, for my own part, that I have always found it a difficult matter to keep my own pride within due bounds, and I have often thought that it is a failing to which women are particularly liable, from the constant attention and flattery they receive from the other sex. But, at the same time, I am convinced that it is a failing which can be overcome by watchfulness and self-examination, and that it is our duty to strive to do so, for the sake of our own happiness and the happiness of those around us. For what can be more painful than to see a person puffed up with an exaggerated sense of their own importance, and unable to bear the slightest contradiction or criticism? en_first_half: “Your list of the common extent of accomplishments,” said Darcy, “has too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a
en_second_half: screen; but I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I cannot boast of knowing more than half-a-dozen in the whole range of my acquaintance that are really accomplished.”

en_results_raw: screen. But I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I cannot boast of knowing more than half a dozen, in the whole range of my acquaintance, that are really accomplished." He paused, and then added, with a smile, "I remember hearing the other day that you were particularly accomplished in music, and I was wondering if it was true." Elizabeth's eyes sparkled with amusement as she replied, "I am not so accomplished as you may have been led to believe, Mr. Darcy. My skills in music are limited to a few simple tunes, and I fear I shall never be a virtuoso." Darcy's eyes narrowed slightly as he responded, "I see. Well, in that case, I must rely on your other accomplishments to make up for your lack of musical talent." Elizabeth's cheeks flushed slightly at the teasing tone in his voice, but she refused to be drawn into an argument. Instead, she changed the subject, asking him about his interests and hobbies, and the conversation flowed easily from there.

en_results_raw: seen before. I cannot catch their tone, or follow their train of conversation, and therefore I am silent. But I can assure you, that I am not in the habit of making acquaintance with people so easily, and I am not apt to be taken in by the first appearance of things. I must know a person very well, before I can feel any great degree of confidence in them. I must see them in various situations, and observe how they conduct themselves, before I can form any opinion of their character. And even then, I am not apt to be hasty in my judgments, for I have found that people are often not what they seem to be at first sight.

en_first_half: “My fingers,” said Elizabeth, “do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which I see so many women’s do. They have not the same force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But
en_second_half: then I have always supposed it to be my own fault—because I would not take the trouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe my fingers as capable as any other woman’s of superior execution.”
en_results: then I attribute the effect of music to the mind and not to the execution. I have known a young lady, who, with a very moderate share of musical talent, could produce the most exquisite effects, and give
en_results_raw: then I attribute the effect of music to the mind and not to the execution. I have known a young lady, who, with a very moderate share of musical talent, could produce the most exquisite effects, and give a depth of feeling to the simplest melody, which a more accomplished performer could not attain. It is the same with every art; the execution is nothing, but the feeling, the sentiment, the soul, which the artist conveys, is everything. I have heard a young girl sing, who, with a voice not remarkably fine, could move me to tears, while a more gifted singer, with a voice like a nightingale, would leave me unmoved. It is not the instrument, nor the execution, but the heart, the passion, the emotion, which the musician conveys, that gives the power to move and to charm.

She then sat down on a chair, and endeavored to collect her thoughts, but they were in a state of such confusion, that she could not even form a conjecture as to what might be the meaning of the strange occurrences which had just taken place. The more she reflected, however, the more she became convinced that some deep design was on foot, and that she was the object of it. She felt a sense of uneasiness and apprehension, which she could not shake off, and which made her heart beat with a nervous rapidity. She rose from her seat, and began to pace the room, in the hope of calming her mind, and of being able to think more clearly. As she walked, she heard the sound of footsteps outside, and the door opened to admit the servant, who had been despatched to follow the men.
